body:
Thanks for the detailed and well articulated report.

We will have to take a look into this. Nothing jumps to my mind on first thought. 

Some follow-up questions:

1) What happens if you move away from the OrtValue setup (i.e.) just feed vanilla numpy arrays to the `session.run()` ? This will tell us if the issue is with the runtime itself or if there is something going on at OrtValue creation time.

2) Is this the only model you are able to repro this behavior with ? Are you able to repro this with a model without Identity in it ?

I tried building the latest master from this commit: 76715ad52560d762f1cfafb2202c962e17d85c44

And I couldn't repro this even after running the repro script a lot of times:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9969784/142527147-69087319-b5eb-4e34-af39-1d658ed1bdee.png)

>     1. What happens if you move away from the OrtValue setup (i.e.) just feed vanilla numpy arrays to the `session.run()` ? This will tell us if the issue is with the runtime itself or if there is something going on at OrtValue creation time.
Nice! It worked just fine without the OrtValue setup! I have some questions then:
1. I thought it was something mandatory when reading the doc? 
2. Am I really using the GPU with that?
3.  What is the use of `ortvalue_from_numpy` in that case?

The function `onnxrt_inference` is now:
```python
def onnxrt_inference(ort_session, arr, device):
    upstreams_onnxrt = {  # removal of the unused inputs
        "input": arr # ort.OrtValue.ortvalue_from_numpy(arr, device, ONNXRT_DEVICE_IDX)
    }
    outs = ort_session.run(
        input_feed=upstreams_onnxrt,
        output_names=OUTPUT_NAMES)
    assert len(outs) == 1
    return outs[0]
```

>     2. Is this the only model you are able to repro this behavior with ? Are you able to repro this with a model without Identity in it ?
No, I just created a minimal example. But I had the issues with bigger models. I really think the cause comes from the OrtValue setup as you suggested.


> I tried building the latest master from this commit: [76715ad](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/commit/76715ad52560d762f1cfafb2202c962e17d85c44)
> 
> And I couldn't repro this even after running the repro script a lot of times

Weird! I just build/installed onnxruntime-gpu from this commit [76715ad](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/commit/76715ad52560d762f1cfafb2202c962e17d85c44) and I still can reproduce this issue :disappointed: - Can you reproduce it with onnxruntime-gpu 1.9.0 maybe?

However! I noticed that for some reasons, I had to change the line 53 of `reproduce_bug_onnxrt_infer.py` from `    for seq_length in range(50):` to `    for seq_length in range(200):` to have some errors at one moment... Weirdly I couldn't reproduced it either for like one minute or two with just 50 seq_lengths... :man_shrugging:. The only difference is that my GPUs are under heavy load right now and that I removed the OrtValue setup before puting it back to test the original script against the new build (and I confirm again that using plain numpy array works very well)

Btw, since there is no Dockerfile to create plain whl file from master for Python 3.9, I created this Dockerfile inspired from your [CUDA Dockerfile](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/master/dockerfiles/Dockerfile.cuda). I'm sharing this, because maybe I did something wrong? I doubt it since I can reproduce the bug from 1.9.0 with an official build... But we never know.

 I added the RTX 2070 (Turing), and RTX 3090 (Ampere) support by adding `75;80;86` to `CMAKE_CUDA_ARCHITECTURES`

```
FROM nvcr.io/nvidia/cuda:11.4.1-cudnn8-devel-ubuntu20.04

ENV PATH /usr/local/nvidia/bin:/usr/local/cuda/bin:${PATH}

ENV TZ=Europe/Paris
RUN ln -snf /usr/share/zoneinfo/$TZ /etc/localtime && echo $TZ > /etc/timezone

RUN DEBIAN_FRONTEND="noninteractive" apt update && apt-get install -y software-properties-common
RUN add-apt-repository ppa:deadsnakes/ppa && apt-get install -y python3.9 python3.9-dev python3-pip
RUN pip install virtualenv

ENV VIRTUAL_ENV=/opt/virtualenv
RUN virtualenv -p python3.9 $VIRTUAL_ENV
ENV PATH="$VIRTUAL_ENV/bin:$PATH"
RUN pip install numpy

ADD . /code
RUN apt-get update && \
    apt-get install -y --no-install-recommends ca-certificates g++ gcc make git aria2 && \
    aria2c -q -d /tmp -o cmake-3.21.0-linux-x86_64.tar.gz https://github.com/Kitware/CMake/releases/download/v3.21.0/cmake-3.21.0-linux-x86_64.tar.gz && \
    tar -zxf /tmp/cmake-3.21.0-linux-x86_64.tar.gz --strip=1 -C /usr
RUN cd /code && /bin/bash ./build.sh --skip_submodule_sync --cuda_home /usr/local/cuda --cudnn_home /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/ \
    --use_cuda --config Release --build_wheel --update --build --parallel --cmake_extra_defines ONNXRUNTIME_VERSION=$(cat ./VERSION_NUMBER) \
    'CMAKE_CUDA_ARCHITECTURES=37;50;52;60;70;75;80;86'
```

I just `docker cp` the wheel file after that to test it in my dev env for now.

Spoke too soon.

I forgot to mention that my repro attempt was on Windows, on Linux I am able to repro it :(

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9969784/142552604-1cc70156-b6d0-4f0d-8931-b493c78ec8a0.png)

So, I guess this doesn't have anything to do with how you built ORT (the Dockerfile comment)

Answering your other questions:

I thought it was something mandatory when reading the doc?
This isn't mandatory. This is just an optional way to send in data to ORT. This is the equivalent of Torch.Tensor (or an initial version of it)

Am I really using the GPU with that?
Yes, Using numpy or OrtValue to send data in has no effect as to where the nodes in your model graph run on. If you send in numpy data and it is "required" on CUDA, ORT will make the copy (as opposed to you creating an OrtValue with memory backing on CUDA). You can use nvidia-smi to check GPU usage.

What is the use of ortvalue_from_numpy in that case?
Well, it is just an interface to create an OrtValue with its data residing on CUDA/CPU memory from a numpy object. It isn't a pre-requisite for using ORT.

It was mostly created in the context of our IOBinding functionality. See some samples here: https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/1541784f6c0e03a6defb8f562f7ae96368dd09ef/onnxruntime/test/python/onnxruntime_test_python_iobinding.py#L7


But this is a good bug to chase down. I will dig into this a bit more.
Btw - are you able to run your script with 1.7 without issues ?

Thank you very much for your reply! It solves my use case at least :partying_face: 


> Btw - are you able to run your script with 1.7 without issues ?

I had some issues, but I managed. The bug is still there on this version. You need to change the `ONNX_OPSET_VERSION` to 13 in the export script and comment the `gpu_mem_limit` argument of the cuda provider in the infer script.

Sadly I can't go before 1.7 since I don't have the proper Python version installed.

Here are the changes:
* New onnx file: [test_bug.onnx.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/files/7567484/test_bug.onnx.zip)


**`reproduce_bug_onnxrt_export.py:`**
```python
import torch
from torch import nn


PARTIAL_SHAPE = (16, 7, 5, 3, 3)  # Problematic shape
# PARTIAL_SHAPE = (7, 5, 3, 3)      # No errors occurs with this shape

ONNX_OPSET_VERSION = 13
ONNX_FILEPATH = "test_bug.onnx"
INPUT_NAMES = ["input"]
OUTPUT_NAMES = ["output"]
DYNAMIC_AXES = {"input": {"seq_length": 0}}
DYNAMIC_AXES = {"input": [0]}
ONNXRT_DEVICE = "cuda"
ONNXRT_DEVICE_IDX = 1


MODEL = nn.Identity()

example_tensors = [torch.ones(1, *PARTIAL_SHAPE)]
torch.onnx.export(
    model=MODEL,
    args=example_tensors,
    f=ONNX_FILEPATH,
    input_names=INPUT_NAMES,
    output_names=OUTPUT_NAMES,
    dynamic_axes=DYNAMIC_AXES,
    operator_export_type=torch.onnx.OperatorExportTypes.ONNX,
    opset_version=ONNX_OPSET_VERSION,
    do_constant_folding=True,
    verbose=False)
```

**`reproduce_bug_onnxrt_infer.py:`**
```python
import numpy as np
import onnxruntime as ort


PARTIAL_SHAPE = (16, 7, 5, 3, 3)  # Problematic shape
# PARTIAL_SHAPE = (7, 5, 3, 3)      # No errors occurs with this shape


ONNX_OPSET_VERSION = 14
ONNX_FILEPATH = "test_bug.onnx"
INPUT_NAMES = ["input"]
OUTPUT_NAMES = ["output"]
DYNAMIC_AXES = {"input": {"seq_length": 0}}
DYNAMIC_AXES = {"input": [0]}
ONNXRT_DEVICE = "cuda"
ONNXRT_DEVICE_CUDA_IDX = 0
ONNXRT_DEVICE_IDX = 0


def create_onnxrt_session(onnx_filepath, device):
    cuda_providers = [
        ("CUDAExecutionProvider", {
            "device_id": ONNXRT_DEVICE_IDX,
            "arena_extend_strategy": "kNextPowerOfTwo",
            # "gpu_mem_limit": 2 * 1024 * 1024 * 1024,
            "cudnn_conv_algo_search": "EXHAUSTIVE",
            "do_copy_in_default_stream": True,
        })
    ]
    cpu_providers = ["CPUExecutionProvider"]

    providers = cuda_providers if device == "cuda" else cpu_providers
    sess_options = ort.SessionOptions()
    sess_options.graph_optimization_level = ort.GraphOptimizationLevel.ORT_DISABLE_ALL
    return ort.InferenceSession(onnx_filepath, providers=providers, sess_options=sess_options)


def onnxrt_inference(ort_session, arr, device):
    upstreams_onnxrt = {  # removal of the unused inputs
        "input": ort.OrtValue.ortvalue_from_numpy(arr, device, ONNXRT_DEVICE_IDX)}
    outs = ort_session.run(
        input_feed=upstreams_onnxrt,
        output_names=OUTPUT_NAMES)
    assert len(outs) == 1
    return outs[0]


def print_result(device, is_session_shared):
    np.random.seed(42)
    session = create_onnxrt_session(ONNX_FILEPATH, device)

    is_good = True
    for seq_length in range(50):
        if not is_session_shared:
            session = create_onnxrt_session(ONNX_FILEPATH, device)
        inps = np.random.randn(seq_length, *PARTIAL_SHAPE).astype(np.float32)
        outs = onnxrt_inference(session, inps, device)
        if not np.allclose(inps, outs):
            max_diff = np.max(np.abs(inps - outs))
            print(f"BUG on seq_length: {seq_length}  -  max_diff: {max_diff}")
            is_good = False
            continue

    if is_good:
        print("Everything went fine")



print("Results with SINGLE inference Session for CPU")
print_result("cpu", is_session_shared=False)

print("Results with SHARED inference Session for CPU")
print_result("cpu", is_session_shared=True)

ONNXRT_DEVICE_IDX = ONNXRT_DEVICE_CUDA_IDX
print("Results with SHARED inference Session for CUDA")
print_result("cuda", is_session_shared=True)

print("Results with SINGLE inference Session for CUDA")
print_result("cuda", is_session_shared=False)
```

issue.title: The inference results are different using onnxruntime-cpu and onnxruntime-gpu

labels.name: ep:CUDA
labels.description: issues related to the CUDA execution provider

labels.name: stale
labels.description: issues that have not been addressed in a while; categorized by a bot

repository.name: onnxruntime
repository.description: ONNX Runtime: cross-platform, high performance ML inferencing and training accelerator

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
using the same onnx model(paddle2onnx), but the inference results using onnxruntime-CPU and onnxruntime-GPU are quite different. The results of onnxruntime-CPU are similar to the model of paddle.

**Urgency**
cpu:
Exported model has been predicted by ONNXRuntime!
ONNXRuntime predict time: 5.0517 s
Paddle predict time: 0.8682 s
The difference of results between ONNXRuntime and Paddle looks good!
relative_diff: 1.0463244e-06
max_abs_diff: 1.1444092e-05

gpu:
Exported model has been predicted by ONNXRuntime!
ONNXRuntime predict time: 1.0025 s
Paddle predict time: 0.9931 s
The difference of results between ONNXRuntime and Paddle looks bad!
relative_diff: 0.29378724
max_abs_diff: 3.240285

**System information**
- OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04): Linux Ubuntu 16.04
- ONNX Runtime installed from (source or binary): pip install onnxruntime-gpu==1.4.0
- ONNX Runtime version: 1.4.0-gpu
- Python version:  Python 3.6
- GCC/Compiler version (if compiling from source): 5.4.0
- CUDA/cuDNN version: CUDA:10.1, cuDNN:7.6.5
- GPU model and memory:

body:
When `OrtValue.ortvalue_from_numpy()` is invoked, we use `cudaMemcpy()` to reflect the numpy buffer's contents to the device memory. 

This is what the [CUDA Runtime API documentation](https://docs.nvidia.com/cuda/cuda-driver-api/api-sync-behavior.html) says about this particular cudaMemcpy operation:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9969784/142802334-f921bf09-82c4-462f-a718-f43077577553.png)

I think what is happening is that sometimes, the numpy array's contents haven't reflected into the cuda device memory and we start processing the input before the copy is complete. We use a non-blocking stream in our sessions to do cuda operations using (i.e..) this stream does not implicitly sync with the default stream and this underlying race condition is the root cause for this bug.

If I add a line to do a default stream sync after the memcpy operation in this function, the bug goes away:
https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/16ddaf564c14436a3978a3f3f3316b899977a5cd/onnxruntime/core/providers/cuda/cuda_provider_factory.cc#L133

I will think about a solution for this. Thanks for reporting this.
Ah! This makes sense! Well done and good news :smiley:

issue.title: Fix potential data race with OrtValue usage in Python

repository.name: onnxruntime
repository.description: ONNX Runtime: cross-platform, high performance ML inferencing and training accelerator

issue.body:
**Description**: 

Problem: When a user creates an `OrtValue` using `OrtValue.ortvalue_from_numpy`,  `cudaMemcpy()` is used to copy contents of the numpy array into cuda device memory. The default stream is used to do this (since OrtValue creation is not tied to a particular session). The [CUDA API doc](https://docs.nvidia.com/cuda/cuda-runtime-api/api-sync-behavior.html#api-sync-behavior__memcpy-sync) states that:

"For transfers from pageable host memory to device memory, a stream sync is performed before the copy is initiated. The function will return once the pageable buffer has been copied to the staging memory for DMA transfer to device memory, but the DMA to final destination may not have completed."

This means that without an explicit sync, the copy between pageable host memory and device memory is not guaranteed to have completed when the `OrtValue` is constructed and ready for use. In our sessions, we use non-blocking compute streams (streams that do not implicitly sync with the default stream) and hence if a user were to send in a CUDA based OrtValue immediately after construction from a numpy array, there could be a data race leading to bad results.

Fix: Sync after the `cudaMemcpy()` used in OrtValue creation.  

**Motivation and Context**
Resolve https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/9799
